turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about SHMEM.
turn.1: What is the difference between a supercomputer and a regular computer?
turn.2: SHMEM SHMEM (from Cray Research’s “shared memory” library) is a family of parallel programming libraries, providing one-sided, RDMA, parallel-processing interfaces for low-latency distributed-memory supercomputers.
turn.3: What does it mean when it says symmetrical hierarchical memory?
turn.4: The SHMEM acronym was subsequently reverse engineered to mean "Symmetric Hierarchical MEMory”.
turn.5: Is there anything else interesting about this article?
turn.6: Later it was expanded to distributed memory parallel computer clusters, and is used as parallel programming interface or as low-level interface to build partitioned global address space (PGAS) systems and languages.
turn.7: What were some of the first applications built using SHMEM?
turn.8: “Libsma”, the first SHMEM library, was created by Richard Smith at Cray Research in 1993 as a set of thin interfaces to access the CRAY T3D’s inter-processor-communication hardware.
turn.10: SHMEM has been implemented by Cray Research, SGI, Cray Inc., Quadrics, HP, GSHMEM, IBM, QLogic, Mellanox, Universities of Houston and Florida; there is also open-source OpenSHMEM.
turn.11: What other foundations did SHMEM lay?
turn.12: SHMEM laid the foundations for low-latency (sub-microsecond) one-sided communication.
